results.title: Dirty pretty things
results.creator_credit: Stephen Frears, Robert Jones, Tracey Seaward, BBC Film Unit and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: An illegal immigrant in urban London, Okwe, is working as a cab driver and doing the nightshift as a hotel receptionist (Chiwetel Ejiofor). He is sharing a flat with one of the hotel’s maids, Senay, (Audrey Tautou’s first English speaking role) who is also an illegal but dreams of escaping to live in America. Initially the film is more a character study of the pair always living in fear of deportation and struggling with poverty but soon develops into a thriller as one night, a gruesome discovery in room 510’s blocked toilet, leads to blackmail and involvement with London’s sordid underworld. Cast includes Sergi Lopez, Benedict Wong and Sophie Okonedo.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, Warner Bros Pictures and Malpaso Company
results.brief_description: Harry Callaghan is a tough, streetwise San Francisco cop whom they call Dirty Harry. In this classic film, you will see why. You will also see why Clint Eastwood’s reputation is secure. No other actor can match his presence. He is magnetising in his portrayal as the shoot-first-ask-questions-later law enforcer who must hunt a psychotic roof-top killer who has slain two people and has kidnapped a girl and threatens to suffocate her if his ransom demands are not met. Harry will get him… one way or the other… no matter what the “system” prescribes. Moody cinematography and stunning location filming propel the story and capitalise upon Eastwood’s commanding presence. Watch this film and ask yourself: Do you feel lucky?

results.title: Dirty deeds
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Deborah Balderstone, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: David Caesar takes an irreverent swipe at the gangster genre with this film set in the milieu of the 60s crime scene in Australia, which owes much to the spirit of more contemporary crime films such as Guy Richie’s “Lock, Stock and two smoking barrels”. It is 1969 and the criminal underbelly of Sydney’s King’s Cross has proven to be a lucrative business for notorious crime boss, Barry Ryan (Bryan Brown). His small-scale local operation is threatened however when the American Mafia catch wind of Barry’s profitable dealings and decide to muscle their way in. The scene is set for a David and Golliath battle between dodgy crooks and dodgier crooks! Caesar’s script is based partly on truth, particularly events surrounding the infiltration of the American mafia into Australian crime. “Dirty Deeds” uses this as a basis however to comment on the subsequent Americanization of Australian culture, while playfully poking fun at the Aussie laissez faire attitude vs American corporate efficiency. Cast also includes: Toni Collette, Sam Neill, John Goodman, Sam Worthington, Kestie Morassi, William McInnes.

results.title: Dirty dancing
results.creator_credit: Emile Ardolino, Linda Gottlieb and Vestron Pictures
results.brief_description: The Summer of 1963 is one that Baby (Jennifer Grey) will never forget. While holidaying in the Catskills she stumbles across the daring and exciting world of the dancing staff; driven by the stirring music and sensual moves, known as “dirty dancing”. She becomes the star pupil of the handsome dance instructor, Johnny (Patrick Swayze), and finds herself becoming more that just his dancing partner. Cast includes Cynthia Rhodes, Jerry Orbach and Jack Weston.

results.title: Pentuphouse
results.brief_description: An aging jazz singer (played with poignant resolve by Gillian Jones) must contend with her highly strung, drug using boyfriend. Director Cate Shortland traces with assured confidence the complex and delicate nuances of aging and compromise within a self destructive relationship.

results.title: Penny serenade [DVD]
results.brief_description: Leaving her husband, a woman contemplating divorce recollects in a series of flashbacks the story of her courtship and marriage, the shattering loss of her unborn child, financial struggles, and the emotional upheaval of adopting a child. Stars Irene Dunn and Cary Grant.

results.title: Disappearing world revisited. Ep. 1
results.creator_credit: Kathryn Ferguson and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: This three part series made for the Discovery Channel draws its material from the landmark Disappearing World documentary series produced by Granada Television in the 1970s. With each of over fifty episodes supervised by an anthropologist, the series set out to record the way of life of indigenous peoples around the world whose traditional cultures were under threat. Each episode of “Disappearing world revisited” briefly recaps three of these original stories then provides a short overview of the situation of these people today. The three stories revisited in Episode 1 are: 1. Mehinacu: The Mehinacu Indians in Central Brazil perform ceremonies to appease the tree spirits. 2. The Kawelka: Ongka’s Big Moka: The Kawelka people of the Central Highlands in Papua New Guinea organise a “moka” (a ceremonial exchange of pigs). 3. Hmong: Hill tribe people of Laos, the Hmong are caught up in the Vietnam War and forced to flee their traditional homes. Presented by Andy Kershaw.

results.title: Dis-Moi Que Tu M'aimes = Tell Me You Love Me
results.creator_credit: Michel Boisrond, Francis Cosne and Gerard Beytout
results.brief_description:
Bertrand and Richard both work in an advertising agency. Richard is married to sweet and submissive Charlotte, whom he treats harshly. Victoire, Bertrand’s wife is less than impressed by this display of chauvinism. Both couple decide to experiment with temporary separation. The men setup camp at the office and the women share a house.

Credits: Producers, Gerard Beytout, Francis Cosne ; director, Michel Boisrond ; writers, Michel Boisrond, Annette Wademant ; photography, Daniel Gaudry ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Mireille Darc, Daniel Ceccaldi, Marie-Jose Nat, Jean-Pierre Marielle, Jean-Pierre Darras.

results.title: Dirty rotten scoundrels
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, Bernard Williams and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: In Beaumont-sur-mer on the French Riviera, Lawrence Jamison (Michael Caine), a suave stylish con man who is an expert at extracting jewels from rich, married women must find a way to deal with crass new competition in the person of Freddy Benson (Steve Martin), a small time scam artist who tells tragic tales about his grandma to secure a few francs from almost anyone! Eventually they decide to compete and make a wager that whoever cannot swindle a certain naive soap heiress (Glenne Headly) for $50,000 must leave the French Riveria hunting ground. A remake of the 1964 “Bedtime stories”.

results.title: Pen point percussion: an introduction to hand-drawn sound of Norman McLaren
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The first part of this film presents an explanation of the principles and production of synthetic sound in motion pictures, showing Norman McLaren’s experimentation with hand-drawn sounds on film. The film is designed as an introduction to McLaren’s animated productions. An oscilloscope records what various sounds look like - the trembling strings of a guitar, the low tones of a tuba, the crow of a rooster and the human speaking voice. Norman McLaren then demonstrates on a moviola the sounds that emit from a soundtrack on which he has drawn dots, lines and triangles and we note how these sounds are synchronised with the artist’s hand-drawn animations. (6 mins.) Written by Don Peter. Photographed by Lorne C. Batchelor. Music by Louis Applebaum. (Award: Venice). The second part presents Norman McLaren’s experimental film ‘Dots’ made in 1948 which demonstrates his innovative technique and illustrates what can be created by drawing directly onto the picture and soundtrack area of film stock. (2 mins.) Other films in the collection related to this technique include ‘The Eye hears the ear sees’, ‘Synchronomy’ and ‘Loops’. (Awards: Toronto, Salerno, Rome)
